page.title: 14Stoke Wood 1
page.content: Stoke Wood covers 26 acres and is at least 400 years old. It is part of the ancient Rockingham Forest and it is managed as a coppiced woodland. It was coppiced in medieval times. The stakes are used for fencing and the hazel binders are used in hedge laying. Clear felling is carried on. Oak trees are cut down when they are 40 to 150 years old. Ash, Silver Birch and Field Maple are cut down when they are 25 to 40 years old. There is a lot of grass in the wood which is evidence that in the past it was used for common grazing. The wood has an Oak, Ash, Silver Birch and Field Maple canopy with Hazel shrubs underneath. On the ground there are a lot of rare plants and so open rides have to be cut to let light in.
